title: So with Rylies at 20% slow and blue buff no long gives 15% AP,... can we buff back the ap items?
body:
Remember when riot wanted to make mages more about utility and buffed Rylies? They subsequently nerfed a lot of the ap items slowly. They also justified it by making blue buff give 15% ap. That's now gone.

The result is AP items were nerfed across the board while {{item:3089}} is super cost ineffective until late game. 

What we have now are low ap items with no reason to justify it.

Riot needs to buff back the ap items and make Death cap cost effective as a second or third item.

Friendly neighborhood math geek here. Based on op.gg, I've compiled average pick rates for every role as comparison for what is a high or low pick rate. The math being a 200% pick rate (There are always 2 champions in each role in each standard game) divided by the viable champion pool for that role. Some off-meta picks will cause minor errors in data, but nothing significant.

Top: 4.651% (43 champions)
Jg   : 5.128% (39 champions)
Mid: 4.651% (43 champions)
Adc: 12.5%   (16 champions) 
Sup: 7.143% (28 champions)

So, yes, 1.5%-2% pick rate is low for mid lane, while a 20% play rate is higher than average for Adc. Just thought I'd chime in is all.

This is normal for riot sadly.

They make a change, do all of the necessary changes to support that change, then when they realize that the change was a terrible decision (half the time so bad that actual implementation was completely unnecessary to come to that conclusion) they half way back peddle, reverting the change, but leaving the complementary changes. As pointed out in the OP, cut the AP from the blue buff, but leave the nerfs to AP items.

This is what happened with the malzahar rework. They tried to push some half baked rework, failed to fix any of his problems, caused more problems to go with it, so they half way back track on the changes, giving him back his flat damage on his R, his flash, Q, E, W, R combo, but not returning his AD play style, removing his new spell shield, or reverting the swarm design of the voidlings.

It's possible that these half reverts were actually the goal of the initial changes, "we want to nerf AP items, but we can't just nerf them, so we buff something else, nerf them in reaction, then remove the buff". But i think it's probably safer to say that it's just incompetence and laziness. I understand when you're working on a kind of extreme development cycle like riot uses, it's tedious to literally code back in the things you just removed. So i think they actually just make a mess trying to spice things up and just leave it not wanting to clean it up.

The funny thing is that the few issues that Malz actually had (if you asked anyone that wasnt an assassin main), were only worsened tenfold while destroying his skillfloor.

New W? Yeah sure lets give Malz on-demand voidlings for 1/10 the original mana cost and 1/3 the original cd and expect his laning isnt actually worse. 
Reduced bases and less burst? Sure lets delete Malz's niche, making him a shitty generalist low range that needs to be overtuned to be relevant.
Shield passive? Sure lets delete one of the glaring weaknesses that allowed Malz to have his laning and overall power, while nerfing his R's counterplay.
Lets put his W on his R? Sure lets delete the only tool Malz has a battle mage to threaten tankiness. While excusing the removed damage from the ult itself.

Every single aspect of the rework was done with such levels of stupidity and a sheer lack of understanding of the champion that it hurted my eyes to read them.

Sadly, I have to agree with this as a Malzahar main. I loved the old and new Malz, but I was disgusted at how much damage I can do with this guy. Even before they half-reverted the changes to his kit, his voidlings were cancer to deal with from the start. Also, as much as I liked the passive shield, it prevents Malz from buying a Banshee's (which is a core item to fight mages with) since any spell can pop both the passive and that item, and I even build Banshee's on this guy back then.

Edit: Surely, Malz is a good example of unhealthy design, but I just can't help and play him as he is my go-to champ when I have a bad day.

For DPS {{item:3165}} is probably stronger than {{item:3089}} (and that's not even mentioning the cost)

CDR
0% ---> 10/10 = 1
10% ----> 10/9 = 1.111 times as many spells
20% ----> 10/8 = 1.25 times as many spells
30% -----> 10/7 = 1.429 times as many spells
40% -----> 10/6 = 1.667 times as many spells

50% = 10/5 = 2 times as many spells (half the cooldown obviously means you get twice as many abilities off in the same amount of time)

0 ---> 20% CDR = 1.25 - 1 = 0.25 (25% increase in DPS)
10% ---> 30% CDR = 1.429 - 1.111 = 0.318 (31.8% increase in DPS)
20% ---> 40% CDR = 1.667 - 1.25 = 0.417 (41.7% increase in DPS)

{{item:3165}} gives 25% - 41.7% increased ability DPS (if abilities are used as soon as possible and you don't buy it while having over 20% CDR)

Yes {{item:3089}} increase AP by 35% BUT for most champions the base damage will be a big part of the damage abilities deal which the % AP increase doesn't affect so the DPS increase will be a lot less than 35% (though of course CDR doesn't help much with up front damage unless the abilities are on a short cooldown like Karthus Q or Cassiopeia E)

I mean MR was buffed when they gave every champ scaling MR. ADC's used to be locked at 30 MR, but now get about extra 8.5 MR throughout the game. It's not huge but it effectively negates the MPen most mages take with their runes.

Liandri's wasnt even a good item (aside its niche heroes) until very, very recently, when they introduced even more MR options for tanks and gave scaling MR to everyone, which made the extra MR kinda of a necesity.

Void Staff became ''too strong'' because it can be actually bought at realistic times while Rabadon is awful on top of unwieldy. The difference for most AP champions between the two items, for their cost, is rather small.

Both items were always niche buys until the latest seasons when they nerfed AP items, made Rabadon unwieldy, and buffed/added Offense&MR hybrid items.

AP itemisation needs more depth.
AD champions have just so much diversity in terms of item, whether you need lifesteal, AS, crit, %armor shred, flat armor penetration, CDR, resistances.
AP items have more or less variations of AP, mana and CDR, despite the AP champions category is as diverse as the AD side.

Also AD items have better passives/actives overall.

Maybe because AP doesn't have to cover anything really different from each other?

Battle mages/tanks can just take the bulkier options like GLP, RoA, Liandries, etc.

Burst/artillery mages take the same shit because all they care about is damage.

AP assassins take stuff that also gives movespeed.

Meanwhile AD has to cover ADCs, AD assassins, juggernauts, on-hit, and AD casters all of which want different things for different jobs.  ADCs need the zeal items to tank/tower bust, AD assassins need lethality to kill squishies, Juggernauts need anti-kite/bulky items to do their job, on-hit needs AS, and casters need CDR so it makes sense that AD has a bigger pool.

Yes and no, AP champions have their categories as much as their AD counterparts.

Battlemages do tons of damage during a protracted teamfight, a could use items that amplify their ability to either slowly kill the frontline or to deal consistent amounts of aoe to the whole enemy team.

Burst mages can create zones of threat, a can 100-0 a squishy target with ease. They can't get past the frontline though, so they could either use items that make them somewhat dangerous to tanks/bruiser (doesn't mean the should be able to oneshot tanks, of course), or items that help them attack the backline with the proper positioning. Also they tend to have some form of CC, that makes them still useful even if they're waiting for their damaging abilities to recharge. But it's better for them to focus on the burst, rather than becoming CC machines. 

AP assassins tend to have more AoE and/or CC than AD assassins, while still having the access to the backline that ad assassins have, and burst mages don't. Katarina has the AoE of burst mages and the mobility of assassins, but lacks the CC that pretty much every burst mage has, while Fizz has some CC and initiation, at cost of some AoE damage (he still destroys single targets). Akali's kit has aged really well so I won't talk about her :P.

And these are just the main categories, that where introduced by riot. If you want you can differentiate mages even further. Heck, Karthus single target Q and Anivia empowered E count as crits, and that's intended, so much that their damage is reduced by randuin. Instead of fixing that, I'd say they should delve deeper into the idea of mages with the ability to crit (of course with the proper items, not with infinity, shiv and such). 
Azir and cassio are considered as some sort of AP carries, why not expand on that? 
Cho is an AP juggernaut, problem is, there's no AP item that properly shreds MR, which means that even his E at high levels doesn't help that much, and he only relies on his R, which is a tad too strong right now. Give him an item that shreds MR and maybe he won't need that much true damage.

But if you're talking specifically about the items AP champs currently have, you're totally right.

Well yea you make a good point here in that there aren't as many ap champs as AD, but they are just as diverse while all using the same small group of items.

AD is used for auto attack damage and ability scaling. Ability power is only used for abilities (hence we call it ability power). If Riot creates a champion and they decide that it shall have scaling abilities but not have scaling auto attack damage then they will use AP scaling. Your champion is an AP champion BECAUSE it was designed not to have scaling auto attack damage. 

Now you are asking for AP items that are equivalent to crit items??? This is complete nonsense. It's ridiculous what kind of bullshit people make up because they literally just want their champions buffed. 

Also if you would actually think before writing you would realize that crit is a percentage boost to raw damage and {{item:3089}} does exactly that for mages.

And Deathcap is the most expensive item in the game (3800), has an awful build path (NLR, Blasting Wand, Amp Tome), _and_ a high combine cost (1265, 1700 if you can't slot in an Amp Tome which is really common).
But you understand that crit is for auto attackers and mages don't need items for auto attack scaling...right?
I mean, Nashor's and Lich Bane disagree a little, but I don't think anyone asked for legit AA scaling AP.
